verses.text: The word of the LORD came to me, saying:
verses.comment: Ezekiel often introduces his prophecies with the formula, 'The word of the LORD came to me.' This emphasizes divine inspiration and true prophetic authority.

verses.text: "Son of man, present a riddle and speak a parable to the house of Israel.
verses.comment: Here, God tells Ezekiel to use a riddle and parable—common teaching tools—to communicate deeper spiritual truths to His people. Jesus would later use parables for similar purposes. (Matt. 13:34)

verses.text: Say, ‘The LORD God says: A great eagle with large wings and long feathers, rich in plumage and of many colors, came to Lebanon and took the top of the cedar.’
verses.comment: The 'great eagle' symbolizes Babylon, and King Nebuchadnezzar, who came to Lebanon, representing Israel. The cedar’s top stands for the ruling leader (king) of Judah.

verses.text: He plucked off the highest branch and carried it to a land of merchants, and set it in a city of traders.
verses.comment: The deportation of Judean royalty to Babylon is depicted here. Babylon was renowned as a land of merchants and traders in ancient times.

verses.text: Then he took some of the seed from the land, and planted it in fertile soil; he placed it by abundant waters and set it like a willow.
verses.comment: The 'seed' refers to Zedekiah, a descendant of King David, who was established by Babylon as a puppet king. Notice the indirect preservation of Davidic lineage, foreshadowing messianic hope.

verses.text: It grew and became a spreading vine of low stature, with its branches turned toward him, but its roots remained under itself. So it became a vine, brought forth branches, and sent out shoots.
verses.comment: The low vine symbolizes the diminished status of Judah under Babylon. Spiritual allegory: humility before God is required for restoration.

verses.text: "But there was another great eagle with large wings and rich plumage. And behold, this vine stretched its roots toward him and sent its branches out to him, seeking from him water to be watered by him in fertile soil."
verses.comment: The second eagle is Egypt, whom Zedekiah turns to for help—breaking faith with Babylon. Spiritual: seeking salvation from worldly powers leads to devastation.

verses.text: "It was planted in good soil by abundant waters, that it might produce branches and bear fruit, and become a noble vine."
verses.comment: God provided every opportunity for fruitfulness; spiritual application: with grace and proper foundation comes growth, but only through faithfulness.

verses.text: "Say: Thus says the LORD God, ‘Will it prosper? Will he not pull up its roots and cut off its fruit, so that it withers? All its fresh shoots will wither, and not by mighty arm or many people, but when he touches it it will wither.’"
verses.comment: Divine judgment is depicted as inevitable and effortless. There is a recurring motif in Scripture: rebellion against God brings spiritual barrenness.

verses.text: "Indeed, being planted, will it thrive? Won’t it wither when the east wind strikes it—wither away in the beds where it grew?"
verses.comment: The 'east wind' is a symbol of Babylonian invasion and God's judgment. Spiritual: only rootedness in God guarantees stability.

verses.text: The word of the LORD came to me, saying:
verses.comment: Repeated emphasis on divine authorship—prophetic messages are not mere human creativity.

verses.text: "Say now to the rebellious house, ‘Do you not know what these things mean?’ Say, ‘Behold, the king of Babylon came to Jerusalem, took its king and nobles, and brought them back with him to Babylon.’"
verses.comment: God explains the parable for clarity. Transparency in teaching and tradition is important for spiritual growth.

verses.text: “He took one from the royal family, made a covenant with him, and imposed an oath on him. He took away the mighty of the land,
verses.comment: The importance of covenants and oaths is highlighted—pointing to the seriousness of divine and ecclesial commitment.

verses.text: so that the kingdom would be humble and would not lift itself up, but keep his covenant and survive.
verses.comment: A humble kingdom is a recurring ideal. In the New Testament, Christ teaches humility as a condition for greatness and survival in God's kingdom.

verses.text: But he rebelled against him by sending his ambassadors to Egypt, that they might give him horses and many people. Will he succeed? Will one who does such things escape? Can he break a covenant and still be delivered?
verses.comment: Rebellion against valid authority is condemned. Strong emphasis on keeping covenants parallels the seriousness of sacraments in Christian life.

verses.text: "As I live," declares the LORD God, "surely in the land of the king who made him king, whose oath he despised and whose covenant he broke, he shall die."
verses.comment: Breaking covenant leads to death—a type of spiritual truth fulfilled in Christ's sacrificial obedience to the New Covenant.

verses.text: Pharaoh with his mighty army and great company will not help him in war, when ramps and walls are cast up to destroy many lives.
verses.comment: Seeking alliance outside God’s plan brings ruin. Trust in worldly power is futile compared to trust in God’s providence.

verses.text: Since he despised the oath by breaking the covenant, and indeed gave his hand and yet did all these things—he shall not escape.
verses.comment: Despising solemn vows carries severe consequences. Spiritual application: faithfulness to one's promises is honored by God.

verses.text: Therefore, thus says the LORD God, ‘As surely as I live, I will bring upon his head my oath that he despised and my covenant that he broke.’
verses.comment: God personally enforces covenant justice. Divine vengeance follows broken promises; compare to fulfillment in Christ, who never broke covenant.

verses.text: I will spread My net over him, and he shall be caught in My snare. I will bring him to Babylon and judge him there for the unfaithfulness he has committed against Me.
verses.comment: Divine judgment is inescapable. God’s authority and justice is exercised through history.

verses.text: All his fugitives with all his troops will fall by the sword, and those who survive will be scattered to every wind. Then you will know that I, the LORD, have spoken.
verses.comment: Scattering is a classic sign of judgment, but also sets up future ingathering—redemptive reversal fulfilled in Christ’s mission (John 11:52).

verses.text: "Thus says the LORD God: I will take from the top of the high cedar and plant it; I will crop off a tender sprig from its topmost branches and plant it on a high and lofty mountain.
verses.comment: Prophetic messianic promise: God plants the Davidic 'sprig' pointing ultimately to Christ and His kingdom—established on the lofty mountain of Zion. (See Luke 1:32)

verses.text: On the mountain height of Israel I will plant it, so that it may bear branches and produce fruit and become a majestic cedar; and under it will dwell birds of every kind—in the shade of its branches they will dwell.
verses.comment: All nations are gathered under the Messianic kingdom, echoing Jesus’ parable of the mustard seed. Spiritual: Unity and universality in God’s church.

verses.text: And all the trees of the field will know that I, the LORD, have brought down the high tree and exalted the low tree, dried up the green tree and made the dry tree flourish. I, the LORD, have spoken and I will do it."
verses.comment: God reverses worldly status—exalting the humble and lowering the proud. Jesus’ teachings mirror this pattern (Luke 14:11; Matt. 23:12).
